reviews.review_msg: He is awesome Professor. His teaching style is learn by doing it yourself. Be prepared for lots of homework, assignments etc. You need to study a lot in order to excel at this course.

great prof hes rlly good at explaining concepts. there were some in class participation activities but overall easy to reach outside of class either in office hours or on piazza. super hard class but hes a great prof

Best professor I've had at SFU. His lecture style is incredibly straightforward and simple; never felt lost. Provided notes are well written and comprehensive. Assignments (later ones) are challenging but very rewarding. No surprises on the exams; what is taught is tested. Will remember 201 as a formative course in my education.

He makes a lot of sense in lectures and is very willing to help students understand. In class activies and labs were really helpful towards assignments. This class was assignment HEAVY. and they are extremely difficult. Plus the environment that we have to code on is really strict and not enjoyable. Great prof, hard course.

Initially disliked Steven for being strict, with no late submission policy. Homework is heavy but essential for CMPT201 and helpful. Exams are fair, covering only class topics. Lectures are excellent; he's passionate, with clear explanations and great notes. Tough class, great professor! Beware there are pop up class activities!

Steven is an excellent teacher! His lectures are engaging, and he explains concepts clearly, so don't miss class. The assignments are the hardest I've done in first 2 years but very rewardingâ€”they teach you the concepts and improve your skills. Exams are fair, and if you complete the work yourself, you'll do well. Be ready to put in a lot of time!

He is very good at teaching!! The long assignments are heavy but that's just CMPT 201. Steve does a great job making sure everyone understands the concepts and he's fairly active on Piazza if you have questions about assignments. Definitely one of the better profs I've had so far.

Steve really cares about his students' learning. He provides lots of examples (code and conceptual) in lectures and is very engaging. The assignments are tough but definitely doable, exams are extremely fair. This course is quite dense (hence 4 credits) but it will completely level up your understanding of everything. So kind and patient, 11/10.

Good stuff, pretty chill guy and assignments are long but fair. also to whoever the yapper was in class that kept talking over him and all that PLEASE CONSIDER LEARNING TO RAISE YOUR HAND!!!!! and shower too buddy

Great professor, you can really tell he loves teaching. If the class didn't understand a concept, he would go over it again with a different example until mostly everybody gets it. Lectures were really engaging and Steve was very enthusiatic. The assignments were challenging, but they weren't impossible to figure out.
CMPT 201: Amazing prof. Very clear and gives candy during lectures. No surprises, your grade will be almost EXACTLY what you'll expect through autograders and very fair exams. Also hi Steve.

he gets the point across in his teaching but his lecture notes are disorganized
4/5 but if he gives me an A+ 5/5

Definitely don't miss lectures. The assignments were very time consuming but prof Ko was so good at teaching the course. I feel like my programming abilities went from a beginner to an intermediate because of all the practice and knowledge I gained from this course. The TAs were also very easy to talk to especially when asking for a regrade or help

The course is tough if you're coming straight from 125, but the workload is fair for 4 credits. Assignments align with lectures, and labs give a good amount of the code. Super nice guy who cares about the material and makes it easy to understand. If you put in the work and manage your time, it'll be easy to get a good grade. Would recommend 100%
he's just a chill guy
Never mess with this guy. The course was assignment-heavy. His teaching seems fine but assignments are just soo much tougher going beyond the lecture material.

Amazing professor. The lectures are simple and engaging. I liked that he used the white board.
The notes on Github are comprehensive and well written.
The later assignments are hard, yes, but they are incredibly well designed and DO drill the topics into your head. Was an amazing learning experience completing them.
Bro drops a  bomb just after/before every long assignment.

Honeslty, lecutres are good I cannot lie, but holly the assignments. They are the worst thing I have experienecd in this degree so far. They are a full time job that you cannot complete. They can take up to 40 hours easily then if you do not figure out one seg fault you just spent 40 hours in your week to get a 0 on a 10% assignemnt.

His long assignments are VERY difficult. You only get 2 weeks to work on each of them but some can take 30-40 hours or even more to complete. Besides that, his lectures and labs are alright. His tests are kinda annoying but aren't worth as much compared to the assignments altogether. Would not recommend 201 with him if you're fresh out of CMPT 125.

Steven Ko is extremely harsh and unforgiving when it comes to minor mistakes. I've never taken a class before where a misclick on an assignment could mean an F and possible academic dishonesty penalties. I just cant support a professor who is so dogmatic that he would punish even honest students for simple mistakes with his scorched earth policies.

The assignments are really difficult and time-consuming but he's a very good lecturer and thorough with his explanations. He knows what he's talking about and takes the time to answer any questions w/o making you feel dumb. He seems passionate about the topic but wanted to challenge students so the assignments are very hard :(. Exams were good tho!

CMPT201 in Spring 2024 is/was not a fun time. The large assignments are extremely difficult for a 2nd year course that can be taken by anyone fresh out of CMPT125. The grade distributions of the 3 large assignments (so far) have had an extreme disparity. Around ~40% of the class failed each assignment with grades almost like an inverse bell curve.
He give me lolipop
He's really accessible outside of class, lectures are really good. Overall Ko is very respected professor. Cmpt201 is worth taking, you'll learn a lot.
Amazing prof, I learned much more in 218 than 300 which none of the assignments in 300 are related to its lecture. He's a really good prof, clear explanations.

Literally biggest mistake... took it to replace cmpt 300 but honestly i should've just taken cmpt 300 instead. If you miss one lecture you will be lost most of the time and the amount of the assignment you get one month before the assignment is insane. No slides, no practice question nothing given just go to the lecture if you wanna pass.

He gives large assignments in Nov that are unreasonable for the expectation they have for the course. This expectation for this course is to be doable for students who have just completed  CMPT 125. The deadlines are too short such that people doing the course have said that he gives assignments as if we don't have other courses to worry about.
not fan of his teaching style. So many assignments ... he gave almost most of big assignments in Nov. Avoid him

"Assignment 11 is going to be easier than assignment 10". Assignments are heavy, his lectures are not enough to deal with assignments. He thrown most of long assignments on us in November... avoid him

No pop quizzes but initially planned to, may do so in the future though so beware. All I can say is he was okay. Lectures were okay but enough to get the idea (lots of self-studying to fully get the content), assignments were tedious but easy so it was okay, quizzes were basically T/F with some short answer but they were okay. Average was a B.
Teaches very well. This class is easier than I thought.

No pop quizzes this term because of COVID. Changed grading scheme during semester (3 "quizzes" of 10%). Unclear assignment grading. Using Nick Sumner's slides. Own slides have mistakes and sounds unsure when teaching. Not accessible during office hours. Recommendation: avoid.
